name: apt
full_text:
Goal: Configure package repositories

This guide explains how to configure package repositories on Ubuntu Server.

Commands:
1. Update the package index
   Command: apt update
2. Install a specific package
   Command: apt install <package_name>

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Configure network settings on Ubuntu

This guide explains how to configure network settings on Ubuntu using the netplan tool.

Commands:
1. 1. Install the netplan tool
   Command: sudo apt update && sudo apt install netplan.io
2. 2. Edit the network configuration file
   Command: sudo nano /etc/netplan/50-cloud-init.yaml
3. 3. Configure the network settings
   Command: sudo netplan apply

name: pvcreate
full_text:
Goal: Manage disk space with LVM

LVM provides a flexible way to manage disk space by dividing it into Physical Volumes, Volume Groups, and Logical Volumes.

Commands:
1. Create a Physical Volume (PV)
   Command: pvcreate /dev/sda2
2. Create a Volume Group (VG)
   Command: vgcreate my_vg /dev/sda2
3. Create a Logical Volume (LV)
   Command: lvcreate -n my_lv -L 10G my_vg

name: cryptsetup
full_text:
Goal: Backup LUKS passwords

Backing up LUKS passwords ensures that you can recover from data loss in case you forget the password.

Commands:
1. Create a backup password
   Command: cryptsetup luksChangeKey <device> -S <key-slot>
2. Add an additional backup password
   Command: cryptsetup luksChangeKey /dev/sda -S 2
3. Back up the passwords
   Command: cryptsetup luksHeaderBackup <device> --header-backup-file <file>
4. Restore passwords from backup
   Command: cryptsetup luksHeaderRestore <device> --header-backup-file <file>

name: apt
description: Manage LVM partitions and volumes on Ubuntu 22.04
full_text:
Goal: Manage LVM partitions and volumes on Ubuntu 22.04

This guide covers the basics of managing LVM partitions and volumes on Ubuntu 22.04, including creating physical volumes, adding them to volume groups, extending volume groups, and renaming volume groups.

Commands:
1. Install the lvm2 package
   Command: apt install lvm2
2. Create a physical volume from a disk or partition
   Command: pvcreate /dev/sda2
3. Add the physical volume to a volume group
   Command: vgcreate myVirtualGroup1 /dev/sda2
4. Extend a volume group by adding a new physical volume
   Command: vgextend VG /dev/sda3
5. Rename a volume group
   Command: vgrename somename-vg vgsomename

name: vgdisplay
description: Manage LVM (Logical Volume Management) in Linux
full_text:
Goal: Manage LVM (Logical Volume Management) in Linux

This guide covers basic operations with LVM in Linux, including listing volume groups, creating and managing logical volumes, increasing and shrinking partitions.

Commands:
1. List VGs
   Command: vgdisplay
2. Create an LV
   Command: lvcreate --name myLogicalVolume1 --size 10g myVirtualGroup1
3. Create a filesystem on the logical volume
   Command: mkfs -t ext4 /dev/myVirtualGroup1/myLogicalVolume1
4. Mount the LV
   Command: sudo mount /dev/myVirtualGroup1/myLogicalVolume1 /test
5. Increase the size of a partition using LVM
   Command: lvextend --resizefs --verbose --size +3G /dev/vg/boot
6. Shrink a partition using LVM
   Command: lvreduce --resizefs --verbose --size -1G /dev/vg/tmp

name: sudo
description: Manage LVM devices using graphical applications
full_text:
Goal: Manage LVM devices using graphical applications

This guide will show you how to manage LVM devices using graphical applications on Ubuntu 22.04.

Commands:
1. Install KDE PartitionManager
   Command: sudo apt-get install partitionmanager
2. Install Blivet-GUI
   Command: sudo apt-get install blivet-gui

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Install LVM on Arch Linux

This guide explains how to install and configure LVM on Arch Linux.

Commands:
1. 1. Install the necessary packages
   Command: sudo pacman -S lvm2
2. 2. Create a physical volume on each disk
   Command: sudo pvcreate /dev/sda1 /dev/sdb1
3. 3. Create a volume group from the physical volumes
   Command: sudo vgcreate MyVolGroup /dev/sda1 /dev/sdb1
4. 4. Create logical volumes within the volume group
   Command: sudo lvcreate -n rootvol -L 15G MyVolGroup

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Install LVM on Ubuntu 22.04

LVM provides flexibility and scalability for disk management.

Commands:
1. 1. Install the lvm2 package
   Command: sudo apt update && sudo apt install -y lvm2
2. 2. Create a physical volume (PV)
   Command: sudo pvcreate /dev/sda1
3. 3. Create a volume group (VG)
   Command: sudo vgcreate myvg /dev/sda1
4. 4. Create a logical volume (LV)
   Command: sudo lvcreate -L 100G myvg

Goal: Manage LVM physical volumes

This guide covers managing LVM physical volumes, including creating and resizing them.

Commands:
1. Create a PV on /dev/sda1
   Command: # pvcreate /dev/sda1
2. Check the PV is created
   Command: # pvs
3. Grow or shrink the PV using pvresize
   Command: # pvresize /dev/sda1
4. Move physical extents before shrinking a PV
   Command: # pvmove --alloc anywhere /dev/sdd1:307201-399668 /dev/sdd1:0-92467

name: pvmove
description: Manage and resize LVM (Logical Volume Management) on Linux
full_text:
Goal: Manage and resize LVM (Logical Volume Management) on Linux

This guide covers various LVM operations, including resizing physical volumes and partitions, creating and managing volume groups, and adding or removing physical volumes.

Commands:
1. Move physical extents to the same partition
   Command: pvmove --alloc anywhere /dev/sdb1:1000-1999 /dev/sdc1:0-999
2. Resize physical volume
   Command: pvresize --setphysicalvolumesize size PhysicalVolume
3. Shrink the partition with your favorite partitioning tool
   Command: partitioning-tool
4. Create a new volume group
   Command: vgcreate MyVolGroup /dev/sdb1
5. Activate a volume group
   Command: vgchange -a y MyVolGroup
6. Deactivate a volume group
   Command: vgchange -a n MyVolGroup
7. Rename a volume group
   Command: vgrename /dev/MyVolGroup /dev/my_volume_group
8. Add physical volume to a volume group
   Command: pvcreate /dev/sdb1; vgextend MyVolGroup /dev/sdb1

description: Remove a partition from an LVM volume group
full_text:
Goal: Remove a partition from an LVM volume group

This guide walks through removing a partition from an LVM volume group.

Commands:
1. Move data to another partition if necessary
   Command: # pvmove /dev/sdb1
2. Specify a physical volume for the move (optional)
   Command: # pvmove /dev/sdb1 /dev/sdf1
3. Remove the partition from the volume group
   Command: # vgreduce MyVolGroup /dev/sdb1
4. Remove all empty physical volumes (optional)
   Command: # vgreduce --all MyVolGroup
5. Remove a missing or failed disk from the group (optional)
   Command: # vgreduce --removemissing --force MyVolGroup
6. Remove LVM metadata from the partition
   Command: # pvremove /dev/sdb1

description: Manage LVM logical volumes and file systems
full_text:
Goal: Manage LVM logical volumes and file systems

This guide covers resizing LVM logical volumes and their associated file systems. It includes examples for extending, shrinking, and calculating the exact size of a logical volume.

Commands:
1. Update configuration files to reference the renamed logical volume
   Command: # update all config files (e.g. /etc/fstab or /etc/crypttab) that reference the renamed LV
2. Extend the logical volume and resize its file system in one go
   Command: # lvresize -L +10G --resizefs MyVolGroup/mediavol
3. Set the size of a logical volume and resize its file system in one go
   Command: # lvresize -L 15G --resizefs MyVolGroup/mediavol
4. Fill all free space on a volume group
   Command: # lvresize -l +100%FREE --resizefs MyVolGroup/mediavol
5. Extend the logical volume without touching its file system
   Command: # lvresize -L +2G MyVolGroup/mediavol
6. Expand the file system to the maximum size of the underlying logical volume
   Command: # resize2fs /dev/MyVolGroup/mediavol
7. Reduce the size of a logical volume and its file system in one go
   Command: # lvresize -L -500M MyVolGroup/mediavol

Goal: Remove a logical volume

To remove a logical volume, first unmount its filesystem and then use `lvremove` to delete the volume.

Commands:
1. Get a list of all logical volumes
   Command: # lvs
2. Look up the mountpoint of the chosen logical volume
   Command: $ lsblk
3. Unmount the filesystem on the logical volume
   Command: # umount /mountpoint
4. Remove the logical volume
   Command: # lvremove volume_group/logical_volume

name: sudo
description: Create and manage LVM snapshots for backup and rollback
full_text:
Goal: Create and manage LVM snapshots for backup and rollback

LVM snapshots allow for consistent backups of file systems by freezing the state of the volume at a specific point in time. This can be useful for rollback purposes or to create a backup that is not affected by ongoing writes.

Commands:
1. Install necessary packages
   Command: sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install lvm2
2. Create a snapshot of the root file system
   Command: sudo lvcreate --snapshot --name snapshot-rootvol MyVolGroup/rootvol
3. Mount the snapshot
   Command: sudo mount /dev/MyVolGroup/snapshot-rootvol /mnt
4. Backup data to the mounted snapshot
   Command: sudo tar -czf /mnt/backup.tar.gz /
5. Unmount the snapshot and merge it with the origin
   Command: sudo umount /mnt && sudo lvconvert --merge MyVolGroup/snapshot-rootvol

Goal: Configure LVM RAID on Linux

This guide explains how to configure LVM RAID on Linux. It covers creating physical volumes, volume groups, and logical volumes using lvcreate --type raidlevel.

Commands:
1. Create physical volumes
   Command: # pvcreate /dev/sda2 /dev/sdb2
2. Create volume group on the physical volumes
   Command: # vgcreate MyVolGroup /dev/sda2 /dev/sdb2
3. Create logical volumes using lvcreate --type raidlevel
   Command: # lvcreate --type RaidLevel [OPTIONS] -n Name -L Size VG [PVs]
4. Create a RAID 0 logical volume
   Command: # lvcreate -n myraid1vol -i 2 -I 64 -L 70G VolGroup00 /dev/nvme1n1p1 /dev/nvme0n1p1
5. Create a RAID 1 logical volume
   Command: # lvcreate --type raid1 --mirrors 1 -L 20G -n myraid1vol MyVolGroup /dev/sda2 /dev/sdb2
6. Create a RAID 5 logical volume
   Command: # lvcreate --type raid5 --stripes 2 -L 40G -n myraid5vol MyVolGroup /dev/sda2 /dev/sdb2 /dev/sdc2

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Configure RAID5 on Ubuntu 22.04

This guide will walk you through configuring a RAID5 volume on Ubuntu 22.04 using LVM.

Commands:
1. Install necessary packages
   Command: sudo apt update && sudo apt install lvm2
2. Create a RAID5 volume group
   Command: sudo vgcreate MyVolGroup /dev/sda2 /dev/sdb2 /dev/sdc2
3. Create a logical volume within the RAID5 volume group
   Command: sudo lvcreate --type raid5 -L 60G -n myraid5vol MyVolGroup /dev/sda2 /dev/sdb2 /dev/sdc2

name: lvcreate
description: Configure LVM for efficient storage management
full_text:
Goal: Configure LVM for efficient storage management

LVM allows for efficient storage management by creating thin pools and logical volumes (LVs) within them. Thin snapshots can be used to save space and improve performance.

Commands:
1. Create a thin pool
   Command: lvcreate -n MyThinPool -V 100G vg0
2. Create a thin LV within the pool
   Command: lvcreate -n SomeClientsRoot -V 30G --thinpool MyThinPool vg0
3. Use thin snapshots for efficient storage
   Command: lvcreate -s vg0/GenericRoot -n SomeClientsRoot

Goal: Troubleshoot LVM commands not working

LVM commands may not work due to missing module or inactive volume groups. Activate volume groups and deactivate them before suspend.

Commands:
1. Load the dm_mod module
   Command: # modprobe dm_mod
2. Try preceding commands with 'lvm'
   Command: # lvm pvdisplay
3. Activate volume groups
   Command: # vgscan
# vgchange -ay
4. Deactivate volume group before suspend
   Command: # vgchange --addtag sleep_umount vg_external

name: umount
full_text:
Goal: Troubleshoot and optimize LVM configurations

LVM configuration issues can cause problems with resizing, snapshot volumes, and thin provisioning. This guide provides solutions to common LVM-related problems.

Commands:
1. Unmount logical volumes before resizing
   Command: umount lv_dev_path
2. Deactivate volume groups tagged with sleep_umount
   Command: vgchange -an vg
3. Change allocation policy to inherit for contiguous LVs
   Command: lvchange --alloc inherit logical_volume

name: sudo
description: Configure network settings on Debian Linux
full_text:
Goal: Configure network settings on Debian Linux

This guide explains how to configure network settings on Debian Linux using the interfaces configuration file.

Commands:
1. Edit the /etc/network/interfaces file
   Command: sudo nano /etc/network/interfaces
2. Configure network settings in the interfaces file
   Command: sudo nano /etc/network/interfaces
3. Bring up the interface with ifup command
   Command: sudo ifup enp7s0

name: ls
full_text:
Goal: Configure network interfaces in Linux

This guide covers configuring and managing network interfaces in Linux, including setting up static IP addresses, configuring DHCP, and troubleshooting common issues.

Commands:
1. List all network interfaces
   Command: ls /sys/class/net
2. Restart networking service to apply changes
   Command: sudo systemctl restart networking

name: sudo
description: Configure network interface settings on Debian-based systems
full_text:
Goal: Configure network interface settings on Debian-based systems

This guide provides step-by-step instructions for configuring network interface settings on Debian-based systems. It covers determining current speed and duplex settings, checking if ethtool is supported by the device, setting interface parameters directly on the kernel driver module (if necessary), changing interface settings to 100 Mbps and full duplex, verifying that the interface settings changed, testing network connectivity by sending data in and out of the system, and saving successful commands to /etc/network/interfaces file.

Commands:
1. Determine current speed and duplex settings
   Command: sudo ethtool eno1
2. Check if ethtool is supported by the device
   Command: sudo mii-tool -v eno1
3. Set interface parameters directly on the kernel driver module (if necessary)
   Command: modinfo MODULENAME
4. Change interface settings to 100 Mbps and full duplex
   Command: sudo ethtool -s eno1 speed 100 duplex full autoneg off
5. Verify that the interface settings changed
   Command: sudo ethtool eno1
6. Test network connectivity by sending data in and out of the system
   Command: ping -c 3 google.com
7. Save successful command to /etc/network/interfaces file
   Command: echo 'iface eno1 inet static' >> /etc/network/interfaces

name: apt
full_text:
Goal: Configure DNS settings in Linux

This guide covers configuring DNS settings in Linux, including using systemd-resolved and modifying nsswitch.conf.

Commands:
1. Install systemd-resolved
   Command: apt install systemd-resolved
2. Enable systemd-resolved
   Command: systemctl enable systemd-resolved && ln -sf /run/systemd/resolve/resolv.conf /etc/resolv.conf
3. Edit nsswitch.conf to use systemd-resolve for resolution
   Command: sed -i 's/hosts:.*files/dns myhostname files/g' /etc/nsswitch.conf

name: echo
full_text:
Goal: Configure network settings on Linux

This guide explains how to configure network settings on Linux, specifically for Debian-based systems. It covers stopping dhclient from modifying the resolv.conf file, setting additional DNS servers and search domains.

Commands:
1. Stop dhclient from modifying /etc/resolv.conf
   Command: echo 'make_resolv_conf() { :; }' > /etc/dhcp/dhclient-enter-hooks.d/leave_my_resolv_conf_alone && chmod 755 /etc/dhcp/dhclient-enter-hooks.d/leave_my_resolv_conf_alone
2. Set additional DNS servers
   Command: echo 'supersede domain-name-servers 12.34.56.78, 12.34.56.79;' >> /etc/dhcp/dhclient.conf
3. Set additional search domains
   Command: echo 'append domain-name " virt vpn";' >> /etc/dhcp/dhclient.conf

name: rm
full_text:
Goal: Configure network interfaces on Linux

This guide covers configuring network interfaces on Linux, including making /etc/resolv.conf immutable, cleaning temporary files in /etc, configuring bridging and VLANs, and reloading the network configuration.

Commands:
1. Make /etc/resolv.conf immutable
   Command: rm -f /etc/resolv.conf && editor /etc/resolv.conf && chattr +i /etc/resolv.conf
2. Clean temporary files in /etc
   Command: find /etc -type f -delete
3. Configure bridging
   Command: echo 'auto br1
iface br1 inet manual
bridge_ports eno1.99 eno2.99
up /usr/sbin/brctl stp br1 on' > /etc/network/interfaces.d/50-br1
4. Configure VLANs
   Command: echo 'auto bond0
iface bond0 inet manual
group bond slaves eno2 eno1
up ifconfig bond0 0.0.0.0 up' > /etc/network/interfaces.d/50-bond0
5. Configure VLAN interfaces
   Command: echo 'auto vlan10
iface vlan10 inet static
address 10.10.10.12/24
vlan-raw-device bond0
gateway 10.10.0.1
dns-search hup.hu
dns-nameservers 10.10.0.2' > /etc/network/interfaces.d/50-vlan10
6. Configure VLAN interfaces
   Command: echo 'auto vlan20
iface vlan20 inet static
address 10.20.10.12/24
vlan-raw-device bond0
gateway 10.20.0.1
dns-search hup.hu
dns-nameservers 10.20.0.2' > /etc/network/interfaces.d/50-vlan20
7. Configure VLAN interfaces
   Command: echo 'auto vlan30
iface vlan30 inet static
address 10.30.10.12/24
vlan-raw-device bond0
gateway 10.30.0.1
dns-search hup.hu
dns-nameservers 10.30.0.2' > /etc/network/interfaces.d/50-vlan30
8. Reload network configuration
   Command: /etc/init.d/networking restart

name: echo
description: Configure MTU on bonded interface and slave interfaces
full_text:
Goal: Configure MTU on bonded interface and slave interfaces

This guide explains how to configure MTU on a bonded interface and its slave interfaces, as well as configuring VLAN devices to use the MTU set on the bond0 device.

Commands:
1. Create a post-up line in the bonding interface configuration to set MTU on bonded interface and slave interfaces.
   Command: echo 'post-up ifconfig eno1 mtu 9000 && ifconfig eno2 mtu 9000 && ifconfig bond0 mtu 9000' >> /etc/network/interfaces
2. Configure MTU on VLAN devices to use the MTU set on bond0 device.
   Command: echo 'vlan-raw-device bond0' >> /etc/network/interfaces

name: sudo
description: Install APT package manager on Ubuntu
full_text:
Goal: Install APT package manager on Ubuntu

APT (Advanced Package Tool) is a command-line package manager for Debian and its derivatives.

Commands:
1. Update the package list
   Command: sudo apt update
2. Install APT
   Command: sudo apt install apt

name: sudo
description: Install systemd on a Linux system
full_text:
Goal: Install systemd on a Linux system

Systemd is a system and service manager for Linux. It provides aggressive parallelization capabilities, uses socket and D-Bus activation for starting services, and offers on-demand starting of daemons.

Commands:
1. Update package index and install systemd
   Command: sudo apt update && sudo apt install systemd
2. Enable and start systemd services
   Command: sudo systemctl enable systemd && sudo systemctl start systemd

Goal: Configure systemd service manager

Systemd is the system and service manager for Linux operating systems. This guide covers basic usage, including listing running services, showing system status, and enabling services to start on bootup.

Commands:
1. List all running services
   Command: $ systemctl
2. Show system status
   Command: $ systemctl status
3. Enable a service to start on bootup
   Command: # systemctl enable example1

name: sudo
description: Change group ownership of files and directories
full_text:
Goal: Change group ownership of files and directories

The chgrp utility is used to set the group ID of files and directories. It can be used recursively with the -R option.

Commands:
1. Install the chgrp utility if it's not already installed
   Command: sudo apt update && sudo apt install coreutils
2. Change the group ownership of a file or directory
   Command: chgrp {{group}} {{path/to/file_or_directory}}
3. Recursively change the group ownership of a directory and its contents
   Command: chgrp -R {{group}} {{path/to/directory}}

name: more
description: Use more command for interactive file reading
full_text:
Goal: Use more command for interactive file reading

The more command is a filter for paging through text one screenful at a time. It provides basic interactive functionality, including scrolling and search.

Commands:
1. Open a file for interactive reading
   Command: more {{path/to/file}}
2. Display help text
   Command: more --help
3. Go to the next page
   Command: <Space>
4. Search for a string
   Command: /{{something}}
5. Exit the pager
   Command: q

name: git
description: Compute the unique hash key of content and optionally creates an object
full_text:
Goal: Compute the unique hash key of content and optionally creates an object

This command computes the unique hash key of content and optionally creates an object with specified type.

Commands:
1. Compute the object ID without storing it
   Command: git hash-object {{path/to/file}}
2. Compute the object ID and store it in the Git database
   Command: git hash-object -w {{path/to/file}}
3. Compute the object ID specifying the object type
   Command: git hash-object -t {{blob|commit|tag|tree}} {{path/to/file}}
4. Compute the object ID from stdin
   Command: cat {{path/to/file}} | git hash-object --stdin

name: id
full_text:
Goal: Display user and group information

The id command displays information about the current user and group identity.

Commands:
1. Display current user and group identity
   Command: id
2. Display current user's ID (UID) as a number
   Command: id -u
3. Display current group identity as a number
   Command: id -g
4. Display an arbitrary user's ID (UID), group ID (GID) and groups they belong to
   Command: id {{username}}

name: sudo
description: Numbering lines in files or standard input
full_text:
Goal: Numbering lines in files or standard input

The nl utility adds line numbers to the output of a file or standard input. It can number all lines, only non-blank lines, or only specific types of lines based on options.

Commands:
1. Install the GNU coreutils package
   Command: sudo apt-get install coreutils
2. Number non-blank lines in a file
   Command: nl {{path/to/file}}
3. Read from standard input and number lines
   Command: cat {{path/to/file}} | nl -
4. Number only the lines with printable text
   Command: nl -t {{path/to/file}}
5. Number all lines including blank lines
   Command: nl -b a {{path/to/file}}
6. Number only the body lines that match a BRE pattern
   Command: nl -b p'FooBar[0-9]' {{path/to/file}}

name: git
description: Analyze and debug Git ignore/exclude files

name: users
description: Display a list of logged in users
full_text:
Goal: Display a list of logged in users

The `users` command displays the list of users currently logged into the system. If no file is specified, it uses /var/run/utmp by default.

Commands:
1. Print logged in usernames according to default file
   Command: users
2. Print logged in usernames according to a given file
   Command: users {{/var/log/wtmp}}

name: lpr
description: Print files using the lpr command

name: echo
description: Print files using the lp command
full_text:
Goal: Print files using the lp command

The lp command is used to print files. It can be used with various options, such as specifying the printer name or number of copies.

Commands:
1. Print a file to the default printer
   Command: echo 'test' | lp
2. Print a file to a named printer
   Command: lp -d {{printer_name}} {{path/to/filename}}
3. Print N copies of a file to the default printer
   Command: lp -n {{N}} {{path/to/filename}}
4. Print only certain pages to the default printer
   Command: lp -P 1,3-5,16 {{path/to/filename}}
5. Resume printing a job
   Command: lp -i {{job_id}} -H resume

name: uptime
description: Print system up-time and other information
full_text:
Goal: Print system up-time and other information

Prints current time, system up-time, number of logged-in users and other information.

Commands:
1. Run the uptime command
   Command: uptime

name: sudo
description: Count the number of unpacked object files and disk space consumed by them
full_text:
Goal: Count the number of unpacked object files and disk space consumed by them

This command counts the number of unpacked object files and disk space consumed by them, to help you decide when it is a good time to repack.

Commands:
1. Install git package
   Command: sudo apt-get install git
2. Count all objects and display the total disk usage
   Command: git count-objects

name: pv
description: Monitor the progress of data through a pipeline
full_text:
Goal: Monitor the progress of data through a pipeline

pv shows the progress of data through a pipeline by giving information such as time elapsed, percentage completed (with progress bar), current throughput rate, total data transferred, and ETA.

Commands:
1. Print the contents of the file and display a progress bar
   Command: pv {{path/to/file}}
2. Measure the speed and amount of data flow between pipes
   Command: command1 | pv --size {{expected_amount_of_data_for_eta}} | command2
3. Filter a file, see both progress and amount of output data
   Command: pv -cN in {{big_text_file}} | grep {{pattern}} | pv -cN out > {{filtered_file}}
4. Attach to an already running process and see its file reading progress
   Command: pv -d {{PID}}
5. Read an erroneous file, skip errors as `dd conv=sync,noerror` would
   Command: pv -EE {{path/to/faulty_media}} > image.img
6. Stop reading after reading specified amount of data, rate limit to 1K/s
   Command: pv -L 1K --stop-at --size {{maximum_file_size_to_be_read}}

name: git
description: Bidirectional operation between a Subversion repository and Git
full_text:
Goal: Bidirectional operation between a Subversion repository and Git

More information: https://git-scm.com/docs/git-svn.

Commands:
1. Clone an SVN repository
   Command: git svn clone {{https://example.com/subversion_repo}} {{local_dir}}
2. Clone an SVN repository starting at a given revision number
   Command: git svn clone -r{{1234}}:HEAD {{https://svn.example.net/subversion/repo}}{{local_dir}}
3. Update local clone from the remote SVN repository
   Command: git svn rebase
4. Fetch updates from the remote SVN repository without changing the Git HEAD
   Command: git svn fetch
5. Commit back to the SVN repository
   Command: git svn dcommit

name: sudo
description: Search for patterns in files using regular expressions
full_text:
Goal: Search for patterns in files using regular expressions

Grep is a command-line utility that searches for patterns in files using regular expressions. It can be used to search for specific text within a file, or to extract specific information from a file.

Commands:
1. Install grep on Ubuntu

name: tput

full_text:

   Command: tput cup {{row}} {{column}}

   Command: tput {{setaf|setab}} {{ansi_color_code}}

name: link

name: sudo

1. Install iconv if not already installed
   Command: sudo apt-get install iconv

   Command: iconv -f {{from_encoding}} -t {{to_encoding}} {{input_file}}

   Command: git range-diff <range1> <range2>

   Command: git range-diff {{commit_1}}^! {{commit_2}}^!

   Command: git range-diff {{theirs}}...{{ours}}

name: sudo

Commands:

   Command: sudo apt-get install coreutils
2. Convert tabs in each file to spaces, writing to stdout
   Command: expand {{path/to/file}}
3. Convert tabs to spaces, reading from stdin
   Command: expand
4. Do not convert tabs after non blanks
   Command: expand -i {{path/to/file}}
5. Have tabs a certain number of characters apart, not 8
   Command: expand -t={{number}} {{path/to/file}}
6. Use a comma separated list of explicit tab positions
   Command: expand -t={{1,4,6}}

name: sudo
description: Configure ALSA to surround51 incl. upmix stereo & dmix, swap L/R, bad speaker position in room
full_text:
Goal: Configure ALSA to surround51 incl. upmix stereo & dmix, swap L/R, bad speaker position in room

This configuration sets up ALSA to use surround51 with dmix and swaps left and right channels. It also enables upmixing for rear speakers.

Commands:
1. Create a new ALSA configuration file
   Command: sudo nano /etc/asound.conf
2. Paste the following contents into the file
   Command: pcm.!default {
    type route
    slave.pcm dmix51
    slave.channels 6

    ttable.0.1 1
    ttable.1.0 1

    ttable.2.3 0.7
    ttable.3.2 0.7
    ttable.4.4 0.7
    ttable.5.5 0.7

    ttable.0.3 1
    ttable.1.2 1

    ttable.0.4 0.5
    ttable.1.4 0.5
    ttable.0.5 0.5
    ttable.1.5 0.5
}
pcm.dmix51 {
type dmix
ipc_key 1024
ipc_key_add_uid false 
ipc_perm 0660 #
slave {
pcm surround51 
rates 48000
channels 6
period_time 0
period_size 1024
buffer_time 0
buffer_size 4096
}
}
3. Save and close the file
   Command: Ctrl+O, Ctrl+X

name: fuser
full_text:
Goal: Troubleshoot sound issues on Linux

This guide helps troubleshoot common sound issues on Linux, including no output, muted sound after reboot, low volume, and random lack of sound on startup.

Commands:
1. Determine if PulseAudio is being used
   Command: fuser -v /dev/snd/*
2. Try using apulse or killing the PulseAudio process
   Command: apulse (or kill PulseAudio process)
3. Run alsactl restore if sound is muted after reboot
   Command: alsactl restore
4. Verify Auto-Mute option in alsamixer
   Command: alsamixer (verify Auto-Mute option)
5. Increase volume sliders in alsamixer if volume is too low
   Command: alsamixer (increase volume sliders)
6. Reset codec settings using hda-analyzer.py
   Command: wget -O hda-analyzer.py https://git.alsa-project.org/?p=alsa.git;a=blob_plain;f=hda-analyzer/run.py && python3 hda-analyzer.py (reset codecs)
7. Add softvol plugin to /etc/asound.conf for low volume
   Command: echo 'pcm.!default { type plug slave.pcm "softvol" } pcm.softvol { type softvol slave { pcm "dmix" } control { name "Pre-Amp" card 0 } min_dB -5.0 max_dB 20.0 resolution 6 }' | sudo tee /etc/asound.conf
8. Restart computer or alsa daemon after adding softvol plugin
   Command: sudo systemctl restart alsa (or reboot)

name: alsamixer
description: Troubleshoot and configure microphone input on Linux
full_text:
Goal: Troubleshoot and configure microphone input on Linux

This guide will help you troubleshoot and configure microphone input on Linux. It covers checking alsamixer settings, testing the microphone with arecord, and configuring pulseaudio.

   Command: arecord --duration=5 --format=dat test-mic.wav

name: amixer

Commands:
1. Mute or set Mic volume to 0%
   Command: amixer sset "Mic" 0% || amixer sset "Mic" mute
2. Remove line from /etc/pm/sleep.d/90alsa
   Command: sed -i '/aplay -d 1 /dev/zero/d' /etc/pm/sleep.d/90alsa
3. Disable channels for nonexistent output devices in alsamixer
   Command: alsamixer
4. Set PCM volume to a level such that gain is 0
   Command: alsamixer
5. Enable softvol in /etc/asound.conf
   Command: echo 'pcm.!default { type plug slave.pcm "softvol" }' >> /etc/asound.conf

name: yay
description: Install and configure mod_gnutls on Arch Linux
full_text:
Goal: Install and configure mod_gnutls on Arch Linux

This guide installs and configures mod_gnutls on Arch Linux. It covers installing the package, adding necessary directives to httpd.conf, and creating a custom configuration file for SSL/TLS settings.

Commands:
1. Install mod_gnutls from the AUR
   Command: yay -S mod_gnutls
2. Add LoadModule directive to httpd.conf
   Command: echo 'LoadModule gnutls_module modules/mod_gnutls.so' >> /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf
3. Include httpd-gnutls.conf in httpd.conf
   Command: echo 'Include conf/extra/httpd-gnutls.conf' >> /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf
4. Comment out Include directive for httpd-ssl.conf
   Command: sed -i 's/^Include conf/extra/httpd-ssl.conf/# Include conf/extra/httpd-ssl.conf/' /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf
5. Create httpd-gnutls.conf file
   Command: echo "..." > /etc/httpd/conf/extra/httpd-gnutls.conf

full_text:
Goal: Implement Logical Volume Manager (LVM) for Linux

LVM provides a flexible way to manage disk space on Linux systems. It allows for resizing and moving partitions around, and a single partition can reside on multiple physical hard disks.

Commands:
1. Install LVM

name: apt
full_text:

name: update-initramfs

name: lvscan

full_text:

   Command: lvscan -a --nohealth

name: mkvg
full_text:
Goal: Install Arch Linux on LVM

This guide provides a step-by-step process for installing Arch Linux on LVM. First, create a new volume group using the mkvg command. Then, format the logical volume using mkfs.ext4.

Commands:
1. Create a new volume group
   Command: mkvg -L 2048 -s 1G /dev/sda5 /dev/sdb5
2. Format the logical volume
   Command: mkfs.ext4 /dev/mapper/MyVolGroup-rootvol

name: pacman
description: Set up LVM on Arch Linux
full_text:

LVM provides more flexibility than traditional partitioning methods.

   Command: vgcreate my_lvm_group /dev/sda1

name: systemctl
full_text:

LVM (Logical Volume Manager) is used to manage disk space on Linux systems. This guide will walk you through the process of configuring LVM on Arch Linux.

Commands:

   Command: systemctl enable lvm2-monitor.service

   Command: mkvgroup vg1 /dev/sda1

name: pacman
description: Set up and manage LVM (Logical Volume Management) on Arch Linux
full_text:
Goal: Set up and manage LVM (Logical Volume Management) on Arch Linux

This guide will walk you through setting up and managing LVM on Arch Linux. It covers creating a new volume group, adding physical volumes, resizing a physical volume, and shrinking a partition.

Commands:
1. Install necessary packages
   Command: pacman -S arch-lvm
2. Create a new volume group
   Command: vgcreate MyVolGroup /dev/sdb1

   Command: pvcreate /dev/sdb1; vgextend MyVolGroup /dev/sdb1

   Command: pvresize --setphysicalvolumesize 500G /dev/sdd1

full_text:
Goal: Remove partition from a volume group

   Command: vgreduce <volume_group_name> /dev/<physical_volume>

name: sudo
description: Resizing Logical Volume and File System
full_text:
Goal: Resizing Logical Volume and File System

Resizing logical volumes and file systems is necessary to maintain the system's performance and security. This process involves updating configuration files, extending or shrinking logical volumes, and resizing file systems.

Commands:
1. Update configuration files
   Command: sudo update-rc.d fstab defaults
2. Extend logical volume by 10 GiB
   Command: lvresize -L +10G --resizefs MyVolGroup/mediavol
3. Set size of logical volume to 15 GiB
   Command: lvresize -L 15G --resizefs MyVolGroup/mediavol
4. Fill all free space on volume group
   Command: lvresize -l +100%FREE --resizefs MyVolGroup/mediavol

name: lvs
full_text:

Commands:
1. Get list of all logical volumes
   Command: lvs
2. Look up mountpoint of chosen logical volume
   Command: lsblk
3. Unmount filesystem on logical volume
   Command: umount /mountpoint
4. Remove logical volume
   Command: lvremove volume_group/logical_volume

full_text:

1. Convert fast disk to PV and add to existing VG

   Command: lvcreate --type cache --cachemode writethrough -l 100%FREE -n root_cachevol MyVolGroup/rootvol /dev/fastdisk

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Configure LVM on Linux

This guide will walk you through the process of setting up LVM on a Linux system. It covers creating a new volume group, logical volumes for RAID 0, RAID 1, and RAID 5.

Commands:
1. Install necessary packages
   Command: sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y linux-firmware
2. Create a new volume group
   Command: sudo vgcreate MyVolGroup /dev/sda2 /dev/sdb2
3. Create a logical volume for RAID 0
   Command: sudo lvcreate -n myraid1vol -i 2 -I 64 -L 70G VolGroup00 /dev/nvme1n1p1 /dev/nvme0n1p1
4. Create a logical volume for RAID 1
   Command: sudo lvcreate --type raid1 --mirrors 1 -L 20G -n myraid1vol MyVolGroup /dev/sda2 /dev/sdb2
5. Create a logical volume for RAID 5
   Command: sudo lvcreate --type raid5 --stripes 2 -L 40G -n myraid5vol MyVolGroup /dev/sda2 /dev/sdb2 /dev/sdc2

   Command: sudo vgcreate MyVolGroup /dev/sda2 /dev/sdb2 /dev/sdc2

name: echo
description: Configure resolvconf for static DNS settings
full_text:
Goal: Configure resolvconf for static DNS settings

This configuration prevents dhclient from modifying /etc/resolv.conf and sets static DNS settings using resolvconf.

Commands:
1. Create a new file in /etc/dhcp/dhclient-enter-hooks.d/
   Command: echo 'make_resolv_conf() { :; }' > /etc/dhcp/dhclient-enter-hooks.d/leave_my_resolv_conf_alone
2. Set execute bit on the new file
   Command: chmod +x /etc/dhcp/dhclient-enter-hooks.d/leave_my_resolv_conf_alone
3. Configure resolvconf for static DNS settings
   Command: echo 'supersede domain-name-servers 12.34.56.78, 12.34.56.79;' > /etc/resolvconf/run/resolv.conf.d/00-resolvconf.conf

name: chattr
full_text:
Goal: Configure immutable /etc/resolv.conf

To make /etc/resolv.conf immutable, run the command chattr +i /etc/resolv.conf. This will set the immutable bit on the file, preventing it from being changed by any package.

Commands:
1. Make /etc/resolv.conf immutable
   Command: chattr +i /etc/resolv.conf

name: sudo
description: Configure bonding interface for multiple IP addresses
full_text:
Goal: Configure bonding interface for multiple IP addresses

This configuration allows multiple IP addresses on one interface using bonding and VLANs.

Commands:
1. Enable bonding interface
   Command: sudo nano /etc/network/interfaces
2. Set bonding mode to 802.3ad
   Command: echo 'bond-mode 4' >> /etc/network/interfaces
3. Configure slave interfaces
   Command: echo 'slaves eno1 eno2' >> /etc/network/interfaces
4. Set MTU on bonding interface and slave interfaces
   Command: sudo ip link set bond0 mtu 9000 && sudo ip link set eno1 mtu 9000 && sudo ip link set eno2 mtu 9000
5. Add IP addresses to slave interfaces
   Command: sudo ip addr add 192.168.1.42/24 dev eno1 && sudo ip addr add 10.10.10.14/24 dev eno2

   Command: echo 'SystemCallFilter=~@mount @cpu-emulation @debug @raw-io @reboot @resources @swap @module @obsolete @clock' > /etc/systemd/system.conf.d/99-systemcalls.conf

   Command: echo 'ProtectHome=true' > /etc/systemd/system.conf.d/99-protecthome.conf

Goal: Configure and manage systemd services

Configure systemd to manage serial consoles and processes.

Commands:
1. Enable serial console
   Command: systemctl enable serial-getty@ttyS0.service
2. Start serial console
   Command: systemctl start serial-getty@ttyS0.service

name: ip
full_text:
Goal: Set up network connection

Follow the steps to set up a network connection on Arch Linux.

Commands:
1. Ensure network interface is listed and enabled
   Command: ip link show
2. Connect to the network
   Command: ip link up eth0
3. Configure network connection
   Command: dhcpcd -D eth0

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Set predictable network interface names

This will disable predictable network interface names and prevent all network interfaces from being renamed to predictable names.

Commands:
1. Install iwd package
   Command: sudo pacman -S iwd
2. Run udevadm test-builtin net_setup_link
   Command: udevadm test-builtin net_setup_link /sys/path/to/network/device

name: dmesg
full_text:
Goal: Fix network configuration issues

Network configuration issues may be caused by broken routers or firewalls. Disabling Window Scaling and updating the system can resolve the issue.

Commands:
1. Check system logs and IP address status
   Command: dmesg | grep -i 'ip addr'
2. Try Wireshark to diagnose TCP issues
   Command: wireshark
3. Disable Window Scaling
   Command: echo > /etc/sysctl.d/99-disable_window_scaling.conf

name: pacman
full_text:
Goal: Configure systemd for Arch Linux

Systemd is the default init system on Arch Linux. This guide will help you configure it.

Commands:
1. Install necessary packages
   Command: pacman -S systemd
2. Enable and start systemd
   Command: systemctl enable systemd

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Override systemd service

Override systemd service settings using drop-in files.

Commands:
1. Edit override file
   Command: sudo nano /etc/systemd/system/unit.d/override.conf

name: mkdir
full_text:
Goal: Set up systemd tmpfiles

Systemd tmpfiles are used to manage temporary files and directories. This guide shows how to set up systemd tmpfiles for a Linux system.

Commands:
1. Create /etc/tmpfiles.d/ directory
   Command: mkdir -p /etc/tmpfiles.d/
2. Create tmpfile for disabling USB wake
   Command: echo "w /proc/acpi/wakeup - - - - USBE" > /etc/tmpfiles.d/disable-usb-wake.conf

name: mkdir
description: Configure systemd to start services after network is up
full_text:
Goal: Configure systemd to start services after network is up

To delay a service until after the network is up, include the following dependencies in the .service file: Wants=network-online.target After=network-online.target

Commands:
1. Create directory for drop-in configuration files
   Command: mkdir -p /etc/systemd/unit/conf.d/
2. Create drop-in configuration file
   Command: echo 'Wants=network-online.target' > /etc/systemd/unit/conf.d/my.conf

name: systemctl
full_text:
Goal: Configure systemd-networkd for Arch Linux

Systemd-networkd manages network configuration and provides a more robust alternative to netctl. It also includes features like DNS resolution and network interface management.

Commands:
1. Enable systemd-networkd.service and systemd-networkd-wait-online.service
   Command: systemctl enable systemd-networkd.service && systemctl enable systemd-networkd-wait-online.service
2. Check if systemd-networkd-wait-online.service is enabled
   Command: systemctl is-enabled systemd-networkd-wait-online.service

name: echo
full_text:
Goal: Configure systemd preset

Configure systemd preset to notify about failed services via email.

Commands:
1. Create top-level drop-in configuration file
   Command: echo '[Unit]
OnFailure=failure-notification@%n.service' > /etc/systemd/system/service.d/toplevel-override.conf
2. Create failure-notification service template unit
   Command: echo '[Unit]
Description=Send a notification about a failed systemd unit
[Service]
Type=oneshot
ExecStart=/path/to/failure-notification.sh %i' > /etc/systemd/system/failure-notification@.service

name: echo
description: Automate email notifications for systemd services
full_text:
Goal: Automate email notifications for systemd services

This script uses systemd-email to send email notifications for specific services. The service can be customized by editing the unit file.

Commands:
1. Create a new unit file
   Command: echo '[Unit]
Description=status email for %i to
User=nobody
Group=systemd-journal' > /etc/systemd/system/status_email_user.service
2. Enable and start the service
   Command: systemctl enable status_email_user.service && systemctl start status_email_user.service

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Optimize systemd service management

Systemd journal file size limit can be increased to improve boot time and system performance.

Commands:
1. Check journal file size limit
   Command: sudo rm -rf /var/log/journal/*; sudo echo 100 > /sys/fs/cgroupjournal_size

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Enable ACL on filesystem housing /var/log/journal

Disable emergency mode to prevent network blocking

Commands:
1. Mask emergency.service and emergency.target
   Command: sudo systemctl mask emergency.service emergency.target

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Understand pacman and its usage

Pacman is the package manager for Arch Linux. It allows users to easily manage packages and keep their system up-to-date.

Commands:
1. Install pacman
   Command: sudo pacman -S pacman
2. Update package list
   Command: sudo pacman -Syu

name: pacman
full_text:
Goal: Install Pacman

Follow the official Arch Linux wiki for instructions on installing Pacman.

Commands:
1. Refresh package list
   Command: pacman -Syu
2. Update system
   Command: pacman -Su
3. Install package
   Command: pacman -S package_name

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Remove package from Arch Linux

Use Pacman to remove a package from Arch Linux. Use the -R option to remove a single package or a group.

Commands:
1. Install Pacman
   Command: sudo pacman -S archlinux
2. Remove package
   Command: sudo pacman -R package_name

name: pacman
full_text:
Goal: Verify package integrity and dependencies

Use pacman to verify the integrity and dependencies of installed packages.

Commands:
1. Search for installed packages
   Command: pacman -Qs
2. Display extensive package information
   Command: pacman -Si package_name
3. Verify package integrity
   Command: pacman -Qk package_name

name: pacman
full_text:
Goal: Automate Pacman Cache Cleanup

Use pacman to clean up the cache and remove unused sync databases.

Commands:
1. Remove all cached packages that are not currently installed
   Command: pacman -Sc
2. Remove all files from the cache
   Command: pacman -Scc

name: pacman
full_text:
Goal: Verify Pacman installation

Verify Pacman installation by checking the version and listing installed packages.

Commands:
1. Check Pacman version
   Command: pacman --version
2. List installed packages
   Command: pacman -Qe

name: echo
full_text:
Goal: Upgrade Arch Linux

To upgrade Arch Linux, uncomment the 'VerbosePkgLists' line in /etc/pacman.conf and run pacman -Syu.

Commands:
1. Enable VerbosePkgLists
   Command: echo "VerbosePkgLists" > /etc/pacman.conf
2. Run pacman -Syu
   Command: pacman -Syu

name: echo
description: Set up Pacman hooks for package management
full_text:
Goal: Set up Pacman hooks for package management

Pacman hooks are used to automate system user and file creation during package installation. This guide sets up two hooks: systemd-sysusers and systemd-tmpfiles.

Commands:
1. Create systemd-sysusers hook
   Command: echo "systemd-sysusers > /dev/null" >> /etc/pacman.d/hooks/sysusers.hook
2. Create systemd-tmpfiles hook
   Command: echo "systemd-tmpfiles > /dev/null" >> /etc/pacman.d/hooks/tmpfiles.hook
3. Update package cache directory
   Command: sudo pacman -Syyu --noconfirm

name: pacman
full_text:
Goal: Update Arch Linux package manager

The pacman package manager needs to be updated to ensure that the system is running with the latest security patches and features.

Commands:
1. Check for outdated packages
   Command: pacman -U /var/cache/pacman/pkg/updates.tar.gz
2. Upgrade all packages
   Command: pacman -Syyu

name: pacman
full_text:
Goal: Fix failed package retrieval

Failed retrieving file error may indicate outdated package lists or repository issues. Try running pacman -Syu to refresh package lists and upgrade.

Commands:
1. Check package list for updates
   Command: pacman -Syu
2. Force a database download
   Command: pacman -Syyu

name: curl
full_text:
Goal: Reinstall pacman

If pacman is broken, use pacman-static to reinstall it and fix dependencies.

Commands:
1. 1. Download pacman-static binary
   Command: curl -L -o pacman-static https://pkgbuild.com/~morganamilo/pacman-static/x86_64/bin/pacman-static
2. 2. Make pacman-static executable
   Command: chmod +x pacman-static
3. 3. Update system with pacman-static
   Command: sudo ./pacman-static -Syu pacman

name: pacman
full_text:
Goal: Reinstall Arch Linux

Reinstalling Arch Linux involves reinstalling the package database and doing a full system upgrade.

Commands:
1. Reinstall packages with pacman -S --overwrite
   Command: pacman -S --overwrite
2. Do a full system upgrade
   Command: pacman -Q $(pactree -u pacman)

name: export
full_text:
Goal: Troubleshooting Pacman

Troubleshooting Pacman involves checking proxy settings, reinstalling broken packages, and updating the system.

Commands:
1. Check proxy settings
   Command: export http_proxy=http://your-proxy:8080 && pacman -S --noconfirm
2. Reinstall broken package
   Command: sudo pacman -U /var/cache/pacman/pkg/your-package.pkg.tar --overwrite
3. Update system
   Command: sudo pacman -Syyu

name: rm
full_text:
Goal: Update Arch Linux

If you receive an error about corrupted packages, try removing the sync directory and updating again.

Commands:
1. Check for corrupted packages
   Command: rm -r /var/lib/pacman/sync/

name: apt
full_text:
Goal: Verify apt command-line interface

Verify the apt command-line interface by running apt update and verifying the package list.

Commands:
1. Run apt update
   Command: apt update -v
2. Verify package list
   Command: apt list --upgradable

name: gnome-terminal
full_text:
Goal: Edit sources list

To use apt, you need to edit your sources.list file. This command will open a terminal and then prompt you to edit the file.

Commands:
1. Open terminal
   Command: gnome-terminal --working-directory=$HOME
2. Edit sources list
   Command: edit-sources

name: apt
full_text:
Goal: Verify APT version

Verify the current APT version and check for any updates. Disable colors to ensure accurate output.

Commands:
1. Check current APT version
   Command: apt --version
2. Check classic commands version
   Command: apt 0.(10 * major + minor)
3. Disable colors
   Command: --no-color apt-get update

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Configure network settings using netplan

Use netplan to configure network settings on Ubuntu 22.04.

Commands:
1. Install necessary packages
   Command: sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y netplan
2. Generate YAML configuration file
   Command: sudo netplan generate --file=/etc/netplan/01-netconfig.yaml

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Configure Netplan network configuration tool

Netplan is a tool for managing network configurations on Linux systems. It provides a simple way to configure network settings using YAML files.

Commands:
1. Install required packages
   Command: sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y netplan
2. Generate and apply the configuration file
   Command: sudo netplan generate && sudo netplan apply

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Configure netplan on Ubuntu

This guide will walk you through configuring netplan on Ubuntu.

Commands:
1. Install necessary packages
   Command: sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y netplan
2. Generate and apply the configuration file
   Command: sudo netplan generate && sudo netplan apply

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Configure Open vSwitch patch ports

This configuration sets up Open vSwitch patch ports and enables IPv6 Privacy Extensions.

Commands:
1. Edit /etc/netplan/01-openvswitch.yaml
   Command: sudo netplan apply
2. Add ports to openvswitch
   Command: echo 'ports: [patch0-1, patch1-0]' >> /etc/netplan/01-openvswitch.yaml

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Enable link-local addresses

To enable link-local addresses, you need to add the following lines to your /etc/netplan/01-netplan.yaml file: 

link-local: [ ipv4 ]
ignore-carrier: true

Commands:
1. Edit /etc/netplan/01-netplan.yaml
   Command: sudo netplan apply

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Configure NetworkManager for IPv6

Configure NetworkManager to use IPv6 and set the default gateway.

Commands:
1. Enable IPv6 support in NetworkManager
   Command: sudo nmcli dev enable ipv6
2. Set default gateway for IPv6
   Command: sudo ip -6 addr add 2001:4::1/64 dev eth0

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Configure netplan for Linux

This guide will walk you through configuring netplan for Linux. First, install necessary packages, then generate and apply the network configuration.

Commands:
1. Install necessary packages
   Command: sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y netplan
2. Generate and apply the network configuration
   Command: sudo netplan generate && sudo netplan apply

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Configure netplan for routing

Configure netplan to set default routes for wider internet

Commands:
1. Install necessary packages
   Command: sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y netplan
2. Create routes file
   Command: echo 'network: { ethernets: { eth0: { routes: [ { to: 0.0.0.0/0, via: 10.0.0.1, metric: 100 } ] } }' | sudo tee /etc/netplan/01-netplan.yaml

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Configure netplan for IPv4

Configure netplan to use DHCP for IPv4 on eth0 interface

Commands:
1. Install necessary packages
   Command: sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y netplan
2. Create a new configuration file
   Command: echo 'network: { ethernets: { eth0: { dhcp4: any } } }' | sudo tee /etc/netplan/01-netplan.conf

name: sudo
description: Configure a Linux network with Netplan
full_text:
Goal: Configure a Linux network with Netplan

Netplan is a tool for managing network configurations on Linux systems. It provides a simple and declarative way to configure networks.

Commands:
1. Install Netplan
   Command: sudo apt-get install netplan
2. Generate configuration file
   Command: sudo netplan generate

name: echo
description: Configure SR-IOV virtual functions for a Mellanox ConnectX-5 SmartNIC
full_text:
Goal: Configure SR-IOV virtual functions for a Mellanox ConnectX-5 SmartNIC

This configuration enables SR-IOV support and sets the operational mode of the embedded switch for a Mellanox ConnectX-5 SmartNIC.

Commands:
1. Enable SR-IOV support
   Command: echo "1" > /sys/class/net/eth0/sriov_num_vf_0", "1" > /sys/class/net/eth0/sriov_num_vf_1"
2. Set the operational mode of the embedded switch
   Command: echo "switchdev" > /sys/class/net/eth0/sriov/eswitch-mode", "switchdev" > /sys/class/net/eth0/sriov/infiniband-mode"

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Configure Wi-Fi using NetworkManager

To use Wi-Fi, you need to install wpasupplicant and edit the network configuration file.

Commands:
1. Install wpasupplicant
   Command: sudo apt-get install wpasupplicant
2. Edit network configuration
   Command: sudo nano /etc/network.conf

name: iw
description: Configure WakeOnWLan and set regulatory domain
full_text:
Goal: Configure WakeOnWLan and set regulatory domain

To improve WiFi performance, enable WakeOnWLan and set the regulatory domain to 'GB'

Commands:
1. Enable WakeOnWLan
   Command: iw config wakeonwlan on
2. Set regulatory domain
   Command: iw regdomain GB

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: configure netplan for bonding

This guide will walk you through the process of configuring Netplan for bonding on Ubuntu.

Commands:
1. enable netplan
   Command: sudo netplan apply
2. create bond configuration
   Command: echo 'bonds:' | sudo tee /etc/netplan/01-bond.conf
3. add interfaces to bond
   Command: echo "interfaces: [enp5s0, enp5s1, enp5s2]" | sudo tee /etc/netplan/01-bond.conf
4. set bond mode to active-backup
   Command: echo "mode: active-backup" | sudo tee /etc/netplan/01-bond.conf
5. apply netplan configuration
   Command: sudo netplan apply

name: echo
full_text:
Goal: Configure bonding interface

Configure the bonding interface to use round-robin mode and set the LACP rate to fast.

Commands:
1. Set bonding mode
   Command: echo bonding_mode = balance-rr > /etc/networking/bonding.conf
2. Set LACP rate
   Command: echo lacp_rate = fast > /etc/networking/bonding.conf

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Configure netplan for bond interface

Configure netplan to manage the bond interface on a Linux system.

Commands:
1. Enable netplan
   Command: sudo netplan apply
2. Set primary port
   Command: sudo ethtool -i | grep bond0 | awk '{print $2}' > /etc/netplan/01-netdev.conf

name: sudo
description: Configure a Linux-based network with WireGuard
full_text:
Goal: Configure a Linux-based network with WireGuard

This guide will walk you through setting up a basic WireGuard network on a Linux-based system.

Commands:
1. Install the required package
   Command: sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y wireguard
2. Create a new WireGuard configuration file
   Command: sudo nano /etc/wireguard/wg0.conf

name: sudo
description: Configure WireGuard and netplan for Ubuntu
full_text:
Goal: Configure WireGuard and netplan for Ubuntu

This guide will walk you through the process of setting up WireGuard and netplan on Ubuntu 22.04.

Commands:
1. Install necessary packages
   Command: sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y wireguard libnetplan-dev
2. Generate public and private keys
   Command: wireguard-keygen -p /path/to/private.key
3. Create netplan configuration file
   Command: sudo nano /etc/netplan/01-wireguard.conf

name: netplan
full_text:
Goal: Configure Overlay Virtual Ethernet (DOVE) clients

Configure DOVE clients to enable notifications, short-circuiting, checksums, extensions, port, and port-range.

Commands:
1. Enable netlink LLADDR and/or netlink IP address miss notifications
   Command: netplan apply --file=/etc/netplan/00-netdev.dove.conf

name: ip
full_text:
Goal: Verify IP routing table

Verify that the IP routing table is up-to-date and not modified by another process.

Commands:
1. Show current routing table
   Command: ip route show
2. Check for any changes in the routing table
   Command: ip route show changed

name: ip
full_text:
Goal: Verify ip command usage

Use ip command with various options to verify its usage and functionality.

Commands:
1. Display help for ip command
   Command: ip -h
2. Print DNS names instead of host addresses
   Command: ip -r
3. Switch to specified network namespace
   Command: ip netns exec <NETNS>

name: sudo
full_text:
Goal: Configure IP routing on Linux

This guide provides step-by-step instructions for configuring IP routing on Linux using the iproute2 package.

Commands:
1. Install iproute2 package
   Command: sudo apt-get install iproute2
2. Verify installation
   Command: ip -c a show route

name: systemctl
description: Verify systemd system and service manager
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemd system and service manager

Use systemctl to list all units and check their status. Verify that the system is running as expected.

Commands:
1. List units with systemctl
   Command: systemctl --all
2. Check unit status with systemctl
   Command: systemctl status <unit_name>

name: systemctl
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemd service status

Verify that the systemd service is functioning correctly by listing its automount, path, and socket units.

Commands:
1. List automount units
   Command: systemctl list-automounts
2. List path units
   Command: systemctl list-paths
3. List socket units
   Command: systemctl list-sockets

name: systemctl
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemd timer status

Use systemctl to check the status of timer units and show runtime information.

Commands:
1. Check current timer units
   Command: systemctl list-timers
2. Show runtime status information
   Command: systemctl status --all

name: systemctl
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemd command usage

Use these commands to manage units in systemd.

Commands:
1. List units currently loaded into memory
   Command: systemctl -a
2. Start one or more units
   Command: systemctl start <unit_name>
3. Stop one or more units
   Command: systemctl stop <unit_name>
4. Reload configuration of a unit
   Command: systemctl reload <unit_name>
5. Restart a unit
   Command: systemctl restart <unit_name>

name: systemctl
full_text:
Goal: Test systemd commands

Test systemd commands with systemctl help and status options.

Commands:
1. Check systemctl help
   Command: systemctl --help
2. Check systemctl status
   Command: systemctl -t status <unit_name>

name: systemctl
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemd mount-image command usage

Verify that the mount-image command is supported by the kernel and can be used to mount an image into a unit's namespace.

Commands:
1. Check if mount-image is supported by the kernel
   Command: systemctl --version | grep mount-image
2. Mount an image into a unit's namespace
   Command: systemctl mount-image foo.service /tmp/img.raw /var/lib/image root:ro,nosuid

name: systemctl
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemd journalctl output

Verify that the systemd journalctl output is working correctly by checking the log targets and listing the unit files.

Commands:
1. Check log targets
   Command: systemctl list-targets --type=service
2. List unit files
   Command: ls /etc/systemd/system/*

name: systemctl
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemd enablement

Check if systemd is installed and then enable a unit to verify the operation.

Commands:
1. Check if systemd is installed
   Command: systemctl --version
2. Enable a unit
   Command: systemctl enable foo@bar.service

name: systemctl
full_text:
Goal: Test systemd command

This command enables a systemd service. Use the correct unit name.

Commands:
1. Enable systemd service
   Command: systemctl enable <unit_name>

name: is-enabled
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemd is-enabled output

Check the exit code and output of is-enabled to verify its functionality.

Commands:
1. Run is-enabled without options
   Command: is-enabled
2. Run is-enabled with full output
   Command: is-enabled --full

name: link
full_text:
Goal: Unmask unit files

Use systemctl link and edit to manage unit files

Commands:
1. Link unit file into search path
   Command: link /etc/systemd/system/myunit.service
2. Edit drop-in snippet
   Command: edit /etc/systemd/system/myunit.service.d/myunit.conf

name: systemctl
full_text:
Goal: Edit unit file

Use the systemctl edit command to invoke an editor on temporary files for editing unit files.

Commands:
1. Invoke editor on temporary files
   Command: systemctl edit --full <unit_file>
2. Write changes to unit file
   Command: systemctl commit

name: show-environment
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemd manager environment block

Verify the environment block passed to all processes spawned by systemd manager.

Commands:
1. Show-environment command
   Command: show-environment

name: log-level
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemd manager configuration

Verify that the systemd manager configuration is correct and that service runtime watchdogs are enabled.

Commands:
1. Check log level
   Command: log-level
2. Check service runtime watchdogs
   Command: service-watchdogs

name: systemctl
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemd boot process

Verify that the current state of the system can be determined using systemctl.

Commands:
1. Check current state
   Command: systemctl -q is-system-running
2. List available states
   Command: systemctl -q list-units --type=state
3. Check boot status
   Command: systemctl -q is-system-booting

name: systemctl
full_text:
Goal: Reboot the system

This command will shut down and reboot the system asynchronously, without waiting for it to complete.

Commands:
1. systemctl reboot
   Command: systemctl reboot --force
2. kexec
   Command: kexec

name: systemctl
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemd command syntax

Verify that systemd commands are used correctly and understand the command syntax.

Commands:
1. Check unit file syntax
   Command: systemctl --help
2. List units with specific type
   Command: systemctl --type=service list-units

name: systemctl
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemd unit file syntax

Verify that the systemctl command behaves as expected for different options and arguments.

Commands:
1. Check for allowed values with help
   Command: systemctl --help
2. List units with specific states
   Command: systemctl -l SUB=active

name: systemctl
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemd service dependencies

Use systemctl to check the status and dependencies of system services.

Commands:
1. Check system status
   Command: systemctl status --full
2. List dependencies
   Command: systemctl list-dependencies

name: systemctl
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemctl command usage

Verify that systemctl is installed and functioning correctly.

Commands:
1. Check system version
   Command: systemctl --version
2. List all running units
   Command: systemctl --list-units

name: man
description: Verify systemd service unit control process behavior
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemd service unit control process behavior

Verify that systemd service units have a single control process and main process as described in the documentation.

Commands:
1. Check systemd service unit documentation
   Command: man systemd.systemctl.1

name: echo
full_text:
Goal: Configure systemd log settings

These settings control how systemd logs are displayed in the terminal.

Commands:
1. Set $SYSTEMD_LOG_COLOR to true
   Command: echo "systemd_log_color=1" > /etc/systemd/log.conf.d/00-systemd-log-color.conf
2. Set $SYSTEMD_LOG_TIME to true
   Command: echo "systemd_log_time=1" > /etc/systemd/log.conf.d/00-systemd-log-time.conf

name: echo
full_text:
Goal: Verify systemd pager settings

Verify that the systemd pager settings are correctly configured to prevent security vulnerabilities.

Commands:
1. Check $SYSTEMD_PAGERSECURE environment variable
   Command: echo \$SYSTEMD_PAGERSECURE
2. Check $LESSCHARSET and $PAGER environment variables
   Command: echo \$LESSCHARSET && echo \$PAGER
